summary.text_en: Mozi and his followers (the Mohists) recorded the world's earliest known written description of the 'Camera Obscura' effect in the text 'Mojing'. By observing the inverted image projected on a wall through a tiny hole, Mozi correctly deduced that light travels in straight lines, like an 'arrow'. This discovery predates the optical works of Aristotle and Euclid in ancient Greece.

story.text_en: Mozi was not just a philosopher but a great scientist and engineer. He wrote in the *Mojing*: 'The image is inverted, because the light crosses at a point.' He used a vivid metaphor: light is like an arrow. Light from the *top* of an object shoots through the hole to the *bottom*; light from the *bottom* shoots to the *top*. He compared this to an oar in a rowlock: when the handle goes down, the blade goes up. He called this crossing point (focal point) the 'end'. This was the first time in history a physical phenomenon was explained using geometric optics.

fun_facts.text_en: Mozi didn't just study pinholes; he also analyzed plane, concave, and convex mirrors, which was extremely practical knowledge at the time (for military signals or starting fires).

The Mohist school declined after the Qin Dynasty's 'burning of books' and the rise of Confucianism. As a result, Mozi's scientific achievements were largely 'forgotten' in Chinese history for nearly 2,000 years, until being rediscovered in the late Qing Dynasty.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Mozi found that if you drill a tiny hole in the wall of a dark room, the tree outside appears 'upside down' on the opposite wall. Why?
Mozi said: Because light walks straight, like an arrow.
Light from the *top* of the tree shoots through the hole to the *bottom* of the wall.
Light from the *bottom* of the tree shoots through the hole to the *top* of the wall.
The light rays 'cross' at the hole, so the image flips. This is the primitive principle of a camera.

applications.text_en: During the Renaissance, painters like Da Vinci used this principle (camera obscura) to accurately trace the perspective of landscapes.

impact.text_en: Mozi's discovery marks an early high point in Eastern science. He was the first person in the world to recognize and experimentally verify that light travels in straight lines. Although his discovery did not spark a continuous optical revolution in China (due to historical reasons), it proves the high level of logic and empirical science achieved by ancient Chinese thinkers.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Ancient Chinese observations of light and shadow

influenced.contribution_en: Shen Kuo (Song Dynasty scientist, who further experimented and detailed pinhole imaging and focal points in 'Dream Pool Essays')
Ibn al-Haytham (who independently discovered and mathematized this principle 1,000+ years later, becoming the father of modern optics)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Mozi was the 'first observer' of optics; through a tiny hole, he saw the nature of light.

quiz.question_en: What fundamental property of light did Mozi's 'Pinhole Imaging' experiment recorded in the 'Mojing' prove?
options_en: The speed of light is finite
Light can be bent by magnetic fields
quiz.explanation_en: Only if light travels in straight lines can the light from the top of the object pass through the hole to the bottom, creating an 'inverted' image. If light curved randomly, the image would be a blur.
